thread.title: Facebook's Oculus must pay $500m in virtual reality lawsuit
thread.title_full: Facebook's Oculus must pay $500m in virtual reality lawsuit | Technology | The Guardian

author: Olivia Solon
title: Facebook's Oculus must pay $500m in virtual reality lawsuit
text:
Facebook-owned Oculus has been ordered to pay half a billion dollars to games company ZeniMax after a jury determined that the virtual reality company’s CEO Palmer Luckey failed to comply with a non-disclosure agreement. 
Who is Palmer Luckey, and why is he funding pro-Trump trolls? Read more 
ZeniMax sued Oculus in May 2014, months after it was acquired by Facebook , alleging that the VR startup improperly used code from ZeniMax to build the Rift VR headset.
ZeniMax is the parent company of ID Software, maker of Doom and Quake games, whose co-founder John Carmack is now the chief technology officer of Oculus . Luckey exchanged emails with Carmack, who was still at ID Software, when he was developing a prototype of the company’s flagship headset.
Oculus plans to appeal the decision and said that the company is committed to the “long-term success of VR”.
The news came as Facebook announced a 51% jump in its fourth-quarter revenue , driven by its mobile advertising business, which accounted for 84% of revenues. Bad publicity over fake news failed to leave any mark on the quarter, which ended 31 December. Revenues rose to $8.81bn and Facebook’s quarterly profit more than doubled to $3.57bn from $1.56bn a year earlier. Some 1.86 billion people were active on Facebook at the end of December, up 17% from a year earlier.
In short, Facebook can afford the $500m.
During closing arguments, ZeniMax’s attorney called for a much larger award – $2bn in compensation and $2bn in damages. Oculus’s attorney, Beth Wilkinson, argued the lawsuit was driven by jealousy and anger, not facts. 
During the three-week trial, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg , testified, characterizing the plaintiffs as opportunists. 
“It’s pretty common when you announce a big deal that people just come out of the woodwork and claim they own some part of the deal,” he said. 
The case was tried in a district court in the north district of Texas. Of the $500m , Luckey will have to pay $50m in the lawsuit, while former Oculus CEO Brendan Iribe has been ordered to pay $150m – both for false designation. The company must also pay $200m for NDA violation, $50m for copyright infringement and $50m for false designation. The jury decided that Oculus didn’t steal trade secrets, as alleged by ZeniMax.
Facebook did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
